poem:
The Town Hall

The hall filled  
with murmurs—  
a storm in voices—  
LaMalfa stood firm,  
a lone tree in  
the shouting gale,  
lines of district change  
tangled in wind.  
  
The rooms of history,  
are they ours?  
The map redraws,  
but who answers  
to whose call?  

Among the clamor,  
questions echo:  
Whose home is it—  
truly?
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "A Trump ally in California is fighting redistricting. Is that what his constituents want? Inside a packed banquet hall in northern California in early August, tensions were flaring. As the representative Doug LaMalfa spoke to constituents in his district, he faced immediate pushback from frustrated audience members who shouted the Republican down. It was the first public town hall LaMalfa had held in Chico, the largest city in his district, in eight years. The booing". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
